Answer: “Should” and “Advanced are both problematic words … but that aside, I’ll give some examples of things that really set us back and then speculate a little.First and foremost - Toba.“Should” and “Advanced are both problematic words … but that aside, I’ll give some examples of things that really set us back and then speculate a little.First and foremost - Toba.Late Bronze Age collapse…Let’s get a little controversial now and pick on religion and colonialism…Speaking of lost knowledge… AlexandriaThe World Wars - Middle East upheavals - Chinese isolationism - Communism …I could keep going - but suffice it to say - we’ve had a lot of fits and starts as a learning species. We take three leaps forward and are smacked back two of them. This pattern has repeated itself many many times for many many reasons - cultural, political, environmental, you name it…So - speculation …There’s a theory going around out there that had we not lost the Library at Alexandria and had Christianity not run roughshod through the West - we probably would have landed a man on the Moon sometime during the 14th or 15th century. Imagine - we would now be in the 600th year or so after man first took to space. Let’s imagine if Mezzo-America were not ravaged by Spain, or Baghdad never fell to the Great Khan - basically imagine we humans were not so prone to clashing violently when cultures first encounter each other, but rather more prone to collaborations, we might have already merged Gravity and Quantum Mechanics a couple of hundred years ago … we may have thought in our current lifetime of cancer as antiquated a problem as bubonic plague. Then again, we might have already produced sapient machines or hyper weapons and gone extinct, or disappeared into virtual reality by now …Basically - the long and short of it is this we are exactly as “advanced” as we “should be” … Because no matter what, there will always be fits and starts - if it wasn’t one thing it would inevitably be another. Learning and progress is a journey of peaks, valleys, detours, switchbacks, circles, and leaps. And while it would be amazing to know Berrosus’ ancient history in three volumes, or the actual original words of Jesus, or the surgical techniques of the pyramid builders, or seen the steam engines and wind turbines invented by Hero of Alexandria… actually accessing those things doesn’t preclude that history would have produced some other unavoidable correction that would have knocked us down a peg or two … or ten.

Answer: I’m going to take my answer in a slightly different direction.You are comparing apples and oranges, not just because of the multiple sectors those companies compete in, but also because Lockheed’s profitability and business model are based on an entirely different dynamic.All of the technology companies you mention are focused primarily on consumer products (although Amazon and Google are increasingly going after US Government projects for cloud computing services).As others have mentioned, Lockheed competes almost exclusively in space and defense. They are contractors and systems integrators,I’m going to take my answer in a slightly different direction.You are comparing apples and oranges, not just because of the multiple sectors those companies compete in, but also because Lockheed’s profitability and business model are based on an entirely different dynamic.All of the technology companies you mention are focused primarily on consumer products (although Amazon and Google are increasingly going after US Government projects for cloud computing services).As others have mentioned, Lockheed competes almost exclusively in space and defense. They are contractors and systems integrators, and they compete for two types of projects, large-scale, decades-long weapons programs and maintenance programs. They also will collaborate with other defense contractors on projects and are occasionally allowed to sellLockheed also works primarily on hardware, which is one of the most difficult and expensive kinds of technology you can work on. There are literally billions of things that can go wrong with millions of component parts that are manufactured by dozens of different companies. Something as simple as aThe projects that defense contractors bid on are few and far between, and in large part, the industry has shrunk from its apex in the 1970s and 1980s at the height of the cold war. Many companies that used to compete with Lockheed either sold out of went out of business because there wasn’t enough money to go around.By comparison, the risk of failure at a software company that focuses primarily on consumer products and services is astronomically low. If a service goes down due to a denial of service attack, you can’t get your email for a few hours - that’s annoying, but no one died. If there is a surge in web traffic on black Friday and the payment processing service goes out, sure you’re losing tens of millions of dollars in lost sales, but more than likely those users will come back at some point in the future and buy things again.Companies like Amazon and Google also have a multitude of revenue streams and lines of businesses. They can afford to experiment and fail many, many times with little or no impact on their core businesses. Their profit isn’t the title wave of funding a company like Lockheed gets on a successful bid, but it is a constant drip of profit that builds to a massive river of profit over time.For example, the most expensive failure Amazon has ever had was the Fire Phone. It probably cost the company $300 million and three hard years of work by hundreds of engineers and designers (I was one of them). A three hundred million dollar loss to Lockheed can happen in a single day with a bad Satelite launch or the stroke of a pen.

Answer: The most important thing is the pitch deck. It will make or break your deal.Guy KawasakiThe most important thing is the pitch deck. It will make or break your deal.Guy KawasakiIn the end, I only care how we are going to make money together, what you are going to use the money for, and how that will result in growth. Everything else is noise.Also, please, for God’s sake, don’t tell me “We have a $200B addressable market, and if we only get 1% of that, we will all be billionaires.” If it were that easy, anyone could do it.Let’s focus on how we make our first $100,000, then our first $1M and then our first $10M. Then we will figure out how to get to $50M and $100M.It is 10x harder to get to $1M than it is to get from $1M to $10M.

Answer: Bill Gates was a seriously good computer programmer, but the key skill he had, and how he got rich, was his business skills, and a bit in his English communications skills. He did not write MS-DOS, he bought it and sold the rights to IBM. He made his zillions with Windows and Office due to his brilliant and occasionally illegal business tactics.Mark Zuckerberg made Facebook using some near trivial web hacking. Probably some Perl or Python, a bit of shell scripts, HTML, CSS, etc. It was his business vision that made his zillions.Business, communications, marketing on top of solid technical skilBill Gates was a seriously good computer programmer, but the key skill he had, and how he got rich, was his business skills, and a bit in his English communications skills. He did not write MS-DOS, he bought it and sold the rights to IBM. He made his zillions with Windows and Office due to his brilliant and occasionally illegal business tactics.Mark Zuckerberg made Facebook using some near trivial web hacking. Probably some Perl or Python, a bit of shell scripts, HTML, CSS, etc. It was his business vision that made his zillions.Business, communications, marketing on top of solid technical skills is how they got where they are. Its not that you just need to learn Java or Rust or some other magic technology.I see questions such as this on Quora all the time. I think they are at best naive. There is no one magic technical bullet. And Bezos, Gates, Zuckerberg and others did not make it rich on technology.

Answer: The tech titans you talk about did not achieve their success because they had mastered computer programming. Although some of them were pretty good programmers, so too were many of their peers. Computer programming is a very basic skill that, although important to good software engineering, is only part of what software engineering entails. And business success requires a whole lot more than good software engineering.Among the things these “tech titans” had were:The tech titans you talk about did not achieve their success because they had mastered computer programming. Although some of them were pretty good programmers, so too were many of their peers. Computer programming is a very basic skill that, although important to good software engineering, is only part of what software engineering entails. And business success requires a whole lot more than good software engineering.Among the things these “tech titans” had were:If you read the history of the computer business you will see that there were hundreds if not thousands of companies that had really clever technology and really excellent technical employees, but which failed - usually because they didn’t have faith in the potential of what they had. A good example is Xerox, whose PARC (Palo Alto Research Center) developed some of the key technology that enabled Apple to succeed.

Answer: I worked with Bill Gates for a short time and knew several people who also worked with him. He is a very bright person and personable. But his talents and skills are in business, not in engineering.He was bright enough to take the BASIC language and jam it into a BASIC ROM which launched Microsoft. He produced a practical version of Unix for personal computers called XENIX. But his engineering talent was modest. And the breadth of his engineering knowledge was small.His engineering motto was: Good Enough.On the other hand, his business talent is extraordinary. He has excellent judgment and forI worked with Bill Gates for a short time and knew several people who also worked with him. He is a very bright person and personable. But his talents and skills are in business, not in engineering.He was bright enough to take the BASIC language and jam it into a BASIC ROM which launched Microsoft. He produced a practical version of Unix for personal computers called XENIX. But his engineering talent was modest. And the breadth of his engineering knowledge was small.His engineering motto was: Good Enough.On the other hand, his business talent is extraordinary. He has excellent judgment and foresight. He listens and learns. He is particularly good at finding talent, molding them into a team, and driving them to a goal. He is particularly good at creating excellent long-term strategies.When IBM approached him to produce an operating system for their new personal computer, Bill Gates did not hesitate in accepting. Within a short time, Gates purchased a suitable operating system from Seattle Computer Products, which he renamed MS-DOS, and hired Tim Paterson. He delivered product on time.One should note that Gates had a working version of Unix, XENIX, up and running and designed for the new microprocessors when he was approached by IBM. But he didn’t push it. Instead, he went out and bought a DOS from Seattle Computer Products.The strategic moves he made over the next decades are legend.Businessmen should aspire to be the next Bill Gates, but programmers have nothing to learn from him except how to identify and work effectively with the best engineers and programmers. If you’re responsible for producing product, that's the way to do it.

And well. He remained Chief Software Architect at Microsoft until he left, more or less. In the late 1970s, he programmed a BASIC language interpreter with colleague Paul Allen.If that was his only achievement, he would still be unheard of. Just another programmer.It is how he took programming, turned it into a product, then turned that into paying customers that makes Bill Gates the household name he is today.Most of our “programmer heroes” follow the same pattern. I was getting stuck all the time.You know what I told myself?I was too old to become a programmI'm turning 27 on July 4th.2 years ago when I was 25, I got my first software engineering job.3 years ago, when I was 24, I didn't know how to code and I thought I was too old to learn programming.At 22, guess what… I also thought I was too old to learn. (After I got my college degree in finance)I had an idea for an app but couldn't find anyone who could build it for me.So I tried to teach myself how to code. I ended up quiting 2 weeks later.You ask why?I founded it too hard. Nothing seemed to work. I was getting stuck all the time.You know what I told myself?I was too old to become a programmer. That was me back when I was 22!So you’re probably wondering what changed years later…At the end of the day, the biggest thing for me was that I stopped making excuses.At 24, I told myself that if I'm truly interested in solving problems and building things, then it's going to require sacrifices.I gave up on going out, I cut out drinking and going to brunch with friends.Not going to lie, along the way I lost some friends.Instead I focused on something I was passionate about.If you are 27 now… and programming is something that you’re interested in … then just go and do it!!!Looking back on my 20’s, I'm most proud of the things that required hard work, lots of struggle and endless sacrifices.It's part of the journey!

He knew the instruction sets of the early microprocessors (late 1970s) and could program in Assembler well enough to make a contribution to the first Microsoft Basic interpreter, and then to the MS-DOS operating system which IBM licensed under the name PC-DOS and launched his little company to fortune and fame. The Microsoft phenomenon wouldn’t have happened without it.Gates has always been primarily a businessman with a business vision, not a programmer. As a product idea generator, Steve Jobs (also not a programmer) was betHe didn’t. He knew the instruction sets of the early microprocessors (late 1970s) and could program in Assembler well enough to make a contribution to the first Microsoft Basic interpreter, and then to the MS-DOS operating system which IBM licensed under the name PC-DOS and launched his little company to fortune and fame. It was the break of a lifetime, a license to print money. The Microsoft phenomenon wouldn’t have happened without it.Gates has always been primarily a businessman with a business vision, not a programmer. As a product idea generator, Steve Jobs (also not a programmer) was better at the game. Even as a programmer in his early years, Gates never worked alone. He always had partners and help. He had an acumen for leadership, a drive to lead, was pragmatically and ruthlessly competitive, and made a lot of sound business decisions.Today, Microsoft has close to 150,000 employees. That’s where all that diverse wealth of programming expertise comes from. There isn’t a line of code by Bill Gates anywhere in Microsoft’s line of software products, and there hasn’t been for a very long time.

Answer: If you Actually want start competitive coding then you must have to follow this method.Step 1Learn C++ or Java. If you can learn C, you can learn C++ and I recommend java first.Why? Because C++ and Java both works on object oriented programming also these are not too complex languages.Againdon't use Python, Ruby, etc, for CP. These are very high-level languages that won't give you as much control over your code as needed.Step 2Get on Hackerrank because it has the best User Interface, combined with relative ease of getting started for the beginners.Ease in the sense that anyone with zero CP/alIf you Actually want start competitive coding then you must have to follow this method.Step 1Learn C++ or Java. If you can learn C, you can learn C++ and I recommend java first.Why? Because C++ and Java both works on object oriented programming also these are not too complex languages.Againdon't use Python, Ruby, etc, for CP. These are very high-level languages that won't give you as much control over your code as needed.Step 2Get on Hackerrank because it has the best User Interface, combined with relative ease of getting started for the beginners.Ease in the sense that anyone with zero CP/algorithms experience will be able to solve the beginner Questions because it’s for everyone.You might get stuck after first 4-5 questions and that's normal. In that case, feel free to see the editorial or google to look for the solution.When you find it, make sure to understand it, and then code it on your own.First, solve "Easy" questions of all sections, and then "Medium" questions.In fact, solving some "Medium" questions is good enough to call yourself a CP professional.And when you make sure that you’re able to solve Medium questions , then start CP on CodeChef that is a much professional practical area to code.Step 3Codechef long contests are the best. Developing your Competitive Programming skills requires that you are both fast and are able to think deeply about a problem.Codechef long challenges = Deep thinking AND Codeforces rounds = Fast codingIf you want to be good, you should try to be good in both these areas.But it's fine if you are just good at long challenges (deep thinking) or just good with short contests (fast thinking), both will help you become a better programmer.Step 4You can try Topcoder if you want. Or just let it be.With CP, if your goal is to get offers from Google HQ and likes, you will have to do it regularly. That is, give contests, try to rank higher, and build your rating.Otherwise, you can just do it on the side and focus on building other practical skills.These practical skills combined with your decent competitive programming experience will go a long way in helping you secure those jobs and internships you dreamed about.Step 5Keep doing this it will take Some time but it is the best way to be a Competitive Programmer.Don’t Be Frustrated.I need Your upvote ,Hit up if you’re also think Programming is Best <3images - Google images
